snippet: The delay in an expected missile strikes left Syria struggling to return to normalcy, with the military and rebels still bracing and everyone uncertain whether an attack would happen at all.
abstract: Syria remains off balance two days after Pres Obama shocked Syrians by delaying expected American missile strikes; country's military is still bracing, rebels are still hoping to capitalize on the confusion, civilians are increasingly fleeing across the borders and everyone is uncertain whether the attack has been called off for good.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by employees of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria, and Beirut; Hwaida Saad from Beirut; Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Scott Sayare from Paris; and Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva.

lead_paragraph: The delay in an expected missile strikes left Syria struggling to return to normalcy, with the military and rebels still bracing and everyone uncertain whether an attack would happen at all.

headline.main: Attacks Delayed, Syrians Juggle Anticipation With Attempts at Normalcy
headline.print_headline: Attacks Delayed, Syrians Juggle Anticipation With Attempts at Normalcy

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
